conversation.content:
[bitter] They won't even let me explain. Twenty years of putting food on the table, keeping a roof over our heads, and now suddenly I'm— I'm what, too dangerous? [pause] Sarah won't return my calls. Won't even tell me what the kids are asking about me. [sad] I know what I did wasn't... conventional. But it was work. It was honest work in its own way. I never brought it home, never let it touch them. [defensive] And now they act like I'm some kind of monster because of a few contracts that went sideways? [sigh] 

God, Lily just turned five. [very sad] She was finally old enough to really remember our fishing trips. And Marcus, he's— he's seven now, right? Seven. [regretful] I missed his birthday last month because of this whole mess. I had his present all wrapped up and everything. Still sitting in my truck. [long pause]

The thing is, I'd, um... I'd do it all different if I could. [quietly] But you can't unmake those choices. You can't unfired bullets. [frustrated] And you can't make people understand that sometimes you do ugly things to protect beautiful ones. [trailing off] Even if those beautiful ones never want to see you again...

subject: The mercenary work that paid your bills just got you blacklisted from ever seeing your grandchildren
